results.title: Kylie Tennant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Kylie Tennant drew her inspiration from people she knew, and her exuberant interview is in itself a valuable piece of Australian social history.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Douglas Stewart
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
Playwright and poet, Douglas Stewart, was for many years the Literary Editor of the Bulletin, and friend of many writers and artists, including Norman Lindsay, Judith Wright and David Campbell.

results.title: Judith Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers I”.
As well as being one of Australia’s more eminent poets and novelists, Judith Wright is an outspoken commentator on conservation and Aboriginal land rights.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers I

results.title: Changing the needle
results.creator_credit: Martha Ansara, Dasha Ross, Mavis Robertson and Jequerity
results.brief_description: One of the consequences of the Vietnam war is a quarter million Vietnamese drug addicts. This film shot in Vietnam in 1981 shows how an underdeveloped war ravaged country is dealing with this problem. Alternative medicine such as acupuncture, natural medicines and exercises play an important part in the rehabilitation process. It also shows a society trying to cope with material scarcity and poverty - the heritage of underdevelopment and the inevitable result of war. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: A Film for Discussion
results.creator_credit: Jeni Thornley, Martha Ansara and Sydney Women's Film Group
results.brief_description:
The Sydney Women’s Film Group was formed in 1971 by a small group of feminists who were troubled by the lack of options for women filmmakers in Australia, and appalled by the depiction of women in the media. The group produced and distributed films, held screenings and discussions, ran production workshops for women, and lobbied for women’s access to film funding and education. “Our aim was to further the spread of our revolutionary ideas through the visual media” (Jeni Thornley). Many of Australia’s women filmmakers owe their inspiration or start to this seminal group’s activities.

‘A Film for Discussion’ is the group’s first production, and is possibly the first feminist film made in Australia. The juxtaposition of experimental and realist sequences in the depiction of a ‘day in the life’ of an ordinary young woman, parallels the ‘personal is political’ ethos of 1970s feminism.

results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Sarah Watt
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.
